botanical_details.genus: Symphyotrichum includes around 90 species of annuals, biennials and perennials, mostly spread through the Americas, that were formerly included within the genus Aster. Leaves are simple, lance-shaped and entire, but it is their daisy-like flowerheads that they are grown for; central disc florets are typically yellow, surrounded by strap-shaped ray florets in shades of pink, blue, purple or white

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in rich, fertile, moisture-retentive soil, in full sun if the soil remains moist throughout the growing season, or in partial shade; mulch every year after cutting down in late autumn. As one of the taller cultivars, it may require support - see staking perennials
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in spring; regular division helps to keep plants healthy and vigorous but is only necessary every few years
how_to_grow.pruning: No pruning required, except cutting stems close to the ground in late autumn
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by eelworm, aphids, slugs, and snails
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by Fusarium foot rot, leaf spot, grey moulds, Verticillium wilt and powdery mildews
